3.verse: Ezekiel was a priest (the son of Buzi) who lived with the Jewish exiles beside the Chebar Canal in Babylon. One day late in June, when I was thirty years old, the heavens were suddenly opened to me and I saw visions from God.

4.verse: I saw, in this vision, a great storm coming toward me from the north, driving before it a huge cloud glowing with fire, with a mass of fire inside that flashed continually; and in the fire there was something that shone like polished brass.

5.verse: Then from the center of the cloud, four strange forms appeared that looked like men,

6.verse: except that each had four faces and two pairs of wings!

7.verse: Their legs were like those of men, but their feet were cloven like calves’ feet, and shone like burnished brass.

8.verse: And beneath each of their wings I could see human hands.

9.verse: The four living beings were joined wing to wing, and they flew straight forward without turning.

10.verse: Each had the face of a man in front, with a lion’s face on the right side of his head,* and the face of an ox on the left side, and the face of an eagle at the back!

11.verse: Each had two pairs of wings spreading out from the middle of his back. One pair stretched out to attach to the wings of the living beings on each side, and the other pair covered his body.

12.verse: Wherever their spirit went they went, going straight forward without turning.

13.verse: Going up and down among them were other forms that glowed like bright coals of fire or brilliant torches, and it was from these the lightning flashed.

14.verse: The living beings darted to and fro, swift as lightning.

15.verse: As I stared at all of this, I saw four wheels on the ground beneath them, one wheel belonging to each.

16.verse: The wheels looked as if they were made of polished amber, and each wheel was constructed with a second wheel crosswise inside.

17.verse: They could go in any of the four directions without having to face around.

18.verse: The four wheels had rims and spokes, and the rims were filled with eyes around their edges.

19.verse: When the four living beings flew forward, the wheels moved forward with them. When they flew upwards, the wheels went up too. When the living beings stopped, the wheels stopped. For the spirit of the four living beings was in the wheels; so wherever their spirit went, the wheels and the living beings went there too.

22.verse: The sky spreading out above them looked as though it were made of crystal; it was inexpressibly beautiful.

23.verse: The wings of each stretched straight out to touch the others’ wings, and each had two wings covering his body.

24.verse: And as they flew, their wings roared like waves against the shore, or like the voice of God, or like the shouting of a mighty army. When they stopped, they let down their wings.

25.verse: And every time they stopped, there came a voice from the crystal sky above them.

26.verse: For high in the sky above them was what looked like a throne made of beautiful blue sapphire stones, and upon it sat someone who appeared to be a Man.

27.verse: From his waist up, he seemed to be all glowing bronze, dazzling like fire; and from his waist down he seemed to be entirely flame, and there was a glowing halo like a rainbow all around him. 28.verse: From his waist up, he seemed to be all glowing bronze, dazzling like fire; and from his waist down he seemed to be entirely flame, and there was a glowing halo like a rainbow all around him. 1.verse: And he said to me: “Stand up, son of dust, and I will talk to you.”

2.verse: And the Spirit entered into me as he spoke, and set me on my feet.

3.verse: “Son of dust,” he said, “I am sending you to the nation of Israel, to a nation rebelling against me. They and their fathers have kept on sinning against me until this very hour.

4.verse: For they are a hard-hearted, stiff-necked people. But I am sending you to give them my messages—the messages of the Lord God.

5.verse: And whether they listen or not (for remember, they are rebels), they will at least know they have had a prophet among them.

6.verse: “Son of dust, don’t be afraid of them; don’t be frightened even though their threats are sharp and barbed and sting like scorpions. Don’t be dismayed by their dark scowls. For remember, they are rebels!

7.verse: You must give them my messages whether they listen or not (but they won’t, for they are utter rebels).

8.verse: Listen, son of dust, to what I say to you. Don’t you be a rebel too! Open your mouth and eat what I give you.”

9.verse: Then I looked and saw a hand holding out to me a scroll, with writing on both sides. He unrolled it, and I saw that it was full of warnings and sorrows and pronouncements of doom.

10.verse: Then I looked and saw a hand holding out to me a scroll, with writing on both sides. He unrolled it, and I saw that it was full of warnings and sorrows and pronouncements of doom.

1.verse: And he said to me: “Son of dust, eat what I am giving you—eat this scroll! Then go and give its message to the people of Israel.”

2.verse: So I took the scroll.

3.verse: “Eat it all,” he said. And when I ate it, it tasted sweet as honey.

4.verse: Then he said: “Son of dust, I am sending you to the people of Israel with my messages.

5.verse: I am not sending you to some far-off foreign land where you can’t understand the language—

6.verse: no, not to tribes with strange, difficult tongues. (If I did, they would listen!)

7.verse: I am sending you to the people of Israel, and they won’t listen to you any more than they listen to me! For the whole lot of them are hard, impudent, and stubborn.

8.verse: But see, I have made you hard and stubborn too—as tough as they are.

9.verse: I have made your forehead as hard as rock. So don’t be afraid of them, or fear their sullen, angry looks, even though they are such rebels.”

10.verse: Then he added: “Son of dust, let all my words sink deep into your own heart first; listen to them carefully for yourself.

11.verse: Then, afterward, go to your people in exile, and whether or not they will listen, tell them: ‘This is what the Lord God says!’”

12.verse: Then the Spirit lifted me up, and the glory of the Lord began to move away, accompanied by the sound of a great earthquake.

13.verse: It was the noise of the wings of the living beings as they touched against each other, and the sound of their wheels beside them.

14.verse: The Spirit lifted me up, and took me away to Tel Abib, another colony of Jewish exiles beside the Chebar River. I went in bitterness and anger, but the hand of the Lord was strong upon me. And I sat among them, overwhelmed, for seven days.

15.verse: The Spirit lifted me up, and took me away to Tel Abib, another colony of Jewish exiles beside the Chebar River. I went in bitterness and anger, but the hand of the Lord was strong upon me. And I sat among them, overwhelmed, for seven days.

16.verse: At the end of the seven days, the Lord said to me:

17.verse: “Son of dust, I have appointed you as a watchman for Israel; whenever I send my people a warning, pass it on to them at once.

18.verse: If you refuse to warn the wicked when I want you to tell them, ‘You are under the penalty of death; therefore repent and save your life,’ they will die in their sins, but I will punish you. I will demand your blood for theirs.

19.verse: But if you warn them, and they keep on sinning and refuse to repent, they will die in their sins, but you are blameless—you have done all you could.

20.verse: And if a good man becomes bad, and you refuse to warn him of the consequences, and the Lord destroys him, his previous good deeds won’t help him—he shall die in his sin. But I will hold you responsible for his death and punish you.

21.verse: But if you warn him and he repents, he shall live, and you have saved your own life too.”

22.verse: I was helpless in the hand of God, and when he said to me, “Go out into the valley and I will talk to you there”—

23.verse: I arose and went, and oh, I saw the glory of the Lord there, just as in my first vision! And I fell to the ground on my face.

24.verse: Then the Spirit entered into me and set me on my feet. He talked to me and said: “Go, imprison yourself in your house,

25.verse: and I will paralyze you so you can’t leave;

26.verse: and I will make your tongue stick to the roof of your mouth so that you can’t reprove them; for they are rebels.

27.verse: But whenever I give you a message, then I will loosen your tongue and let you speak, and you shall say to them: ‘The Lord God says.’ Let anyone listen who wants to, and let anyone refuse who wants to, for they are rebels.

1.verse: “And now, son of dust, take a large brick and lay it before you and draw a map of the city of Jerusalem on it. Draw a picture of siege mounds being built against the city, put enemy camps around it and battering rams surrounding the walls.

2.verse: “And now, son of dust, take a large brick and lay it before you and draw a map of the city of Jerusalem on it. Draw a picture of siege mounds being built against the city, put enemy camps around it and battering rams surrounding the walls.

3.verse: And put an iron plate between you and the city, like a wall of iron. Demonstrate how an enemy army will capture Jerusalem! “There is special meaning in each detail of what I have told you to do. For it is a warning to the people of Israel.

4.verse: “Now lie on your left side for 390 days, to show that Israel will be punished for 390 years by captivity and doom. Each day you lie there represents a year of punishment ahead for Israel.

5.verse: “Now lie on your left side for 390 days, to show that Israel will be punished for 390 years by captivity and doom. Each day you lie there represents a year of punishment ahead for Israel.

6.verse: Afterwards, turn over and lie on your right side for forty days, to signify the years of Judah’s punishment. Each day will represent one year.

7.verse: “Meanwhile continue your demonstration of the siege of Jerusalem; lie there with your arm bared to signify great strength and power in the attack against her. This will prophesy her doom.

8.verse: And I will paralyze you so that you can’t turn over from one side to the other until you have completed all the days of your siege.

9.verse: “During the first 390 days eat bread made of flour mixed from wheat, barley, beans, lentils, and spelt. Mix the various kinds of flour together in a jar.

10.verse: You are to ration this out to yourself at the rate of eight ounces at a time, one meal a day.

11.verse: And use one quart of water a day; don’t use more than that.

12.verse: Each day take flour from the barrel and prepare it as you would barley cakes. While all the people are watching, bake it over a fire, using dried human dung as fuel, and eat it.

13.verse: For the Lord declares, Israel shall eat defiled bread in the Gentile lands to which I exile them!”

14.verse: Then I said, “O Lord God, must I be defiled by using dung? For I have never been defiled before in all my life. From the time I was a child until now I have never eaten any animal that died of sickness or that I found injured or dead; and I have never eaten any of the kinds of animals our law forbids.”

15.verse: Then the Lord said, “All right, you may use cow dung instead of human dung.”

16.verse: Then he told me, “Son of dust, bread will be tightly rationed in Jerusalem. It will be weighed out with great care and eaten fearfully. And the water will be portioned out in driblets, and the people will drink it with dismay.

17.verse: I will cause the people to lack both bread and water; they will look at one another in frantic terror and waste away beneath their punishment.

1.verse: “Son of dust, take a sharp sword and use it as a barber’s razor to shave your head and beard; use balances to weigh the hair into three equal parts.

2.verse: Place a third of it at the center of your map of Jerusalem. After your siege, burn it there. Scatter another third across your map and slash at it with a knife. Scatter the last third to the wind, for I will chase my people with the sword.

3.verse: Keep just a bit of the hair and tie it up in your robe;

4.verse: then take a few hairs out and throw them into the fire, for a fire shall come from this remnant and destroy all Israel.”

5.verse: The Lord God says, “This illustrates what will happen to Jerusalem, for she has turned away from my laws and has been even more wicked than the nations surrounding her.”

8.verse: Therefore the Lord God says: “I, even I, am against you and will punish you publicly while all the nations watch.

9.verse: Because of the terrible sins you have committed, I will punish you more terribly than I have ever done before or ever will again.

10.verse: Fathers will eat their own sons, and sons will eat their fathers; and those who survive will be scattered into all the world.

11.verse: “For I promise you: Because you have defiled my Temple with idols and evil sacrifices, therefore I will not spare you nor pity you at all.

12.verse: One-third of you will die from famine and disease; one-third will be slaughtered by the enemy; and one-third I will scatter to the winds, sending the sword of the enemy chasing after you.

13.verse: Then at last my anger will be appeased. And all Israel will know that what I threaten I do.

14.verse: “So I will make a public example of you before all the surrounding nations and before everyone traveling past the ruins of your land.

15.verse: You will become a laughingstock to the world and an awesome example to everyone, for all to see what happens when the Lord turns against an entire nation in furious rebuke. I, the Lord, have spoken it!

16.verse: “I will shower you with deadly arrows of famine to destroy you. The famine will become more and more serious until every bit of bread is gone.

17.verse: And not only famine will come, but wild animals will attack and kill you and your families; disease and war will stalk your land, and the sword of the enemy will slay you; I, the Lord, have spoken it!”

3.verse: Say to them, ‘O mountains of Israel, hear the message of the Lord God against you and against the rivers and valleys. I, even I the Lord, will bring war upon you to destroy your idols.

4.verse: All your cities will be smashed and burned, and the idol altars abandoned. Your gods will be shattered; the bones of their worshipers will lie scattered among the altars. Then at last you will know I am the Lord.

10.verse: They will realize that I alone am God and that I wasn’t fooling when I told them that all this would happen to them.’”

11.verse: The Lord God says: “Raise your hands in horror and shake your head with deep remorse and say, ‘Alas for all the evil we have done!’ For you are going to perish from war and famine and disease.

12.verse: Disease will strike down those in exile; war will destroy those in the land of Israel; and any who remain will die by famine and siege. So at last I will expend my fury on you.

13.verse: When your slain lie scattered among your idols and altars on every hill and mountain and under every green tree and great oak where they offered incense to their gods—you will realize that I alone am God.

14.verse: I will crush you and make your cities desolate from the wilderness in the south to Riblah in the north. Then you will know I am the Lord.”

1.verse: This further message came to me from God:

2.verse: “Tell Israel, ‘Wherever you look—east, west, north, or south—your land is finished.

3.verse: No hope remains, for I will loose my anger on you for your worshiping of idols.

4.verse: I will turn my eyes away and show no pity; I will repay you in full, and you shall know I am the Lord.’”

5.verse: The Lord God says: “With one blow after another I will finish you. The end has come; your final doom is waiting.

6.verse: The Lord God says: “With one blow after another I will finish you. The end has come; your final doom is waiting.

7.verse: O Israel, the day of your damnation dawns; the time has come; the day of trouble nears. It is a day of shouts of anguish, not shouts of joy!

8.verse: Soon I will pour out my fury and let it finish its work of punishing you for all your evil deeds. I will not spare nor pity you, and you will know that I, the Lord, am doing it.

10.verse: The day of judgment has come; the morning dawns, for your wickedness and pride have run their course and reached their climax—none of these rich and wicked men of pride shall live. All your boasting will die away, and no one will be left to bewail your fate.

11.verse: The day of judgment has come; the morning dawns, for your wickedness and pride have run their course and reached their climax—none of these rich and wicked men of pride shall live. All your boasting will die away, and no one will be left to bewail your fate.

12.verse: “Yes, the time has come; the day draws near. There will be nothing to buy or sell, for the wrath of God is on the land.

13.verse: And even if a merchant lives, his business will be gone, for God has spoken against all the people of Israel; all will be destroyed. Not one of those whose lives are filled with sin will recover.

14.verse: “The trumpets shout to Israel’s army, ‘Mobilize!’ but no one listens, for my wrath is on them all.

15.verse: If you go outside the walls, there stands the enemy to kill you. If you stay inside, famine and disease will devour you.

16.verse: Any who escape will be lonely as mourning doves hiding on the mountains, each weeping for his sins.

17.verse: All hands shall be feeble, and all knees as weak as water.

18.verse: You shall clothe yourselves with sackcloth, and horror and shame shall cover you; you shall shave your heads in sorrow and remorse.

19.verse: “Throw away your money! Toss it out like worthless rubbish, for it will have no value in that day of wrath. It will neither satisfy nor feed you, for your love of money is the reason for your sin.

20.verse: I gave you gold to use in decorating the Temple, and you used it instead to make idols! Therefore, I will take it all away from you.

21.verse: I will give it to foreigners and to wicked men as booty. They shall defile my Temple.

22.verse: I will not look when they defile it, nor will I stop them. Like robbers, they will loot the treasures and leave the Temple in ruins.

23.verse: “Prepare chains for my people, for the land is full of bloody crimes. Jerusalem is filled with violence, so I will enslave her people.

24.verse: I will crush your pride by bringing to Jerusalem the worst of the nations to occupy your homes, break down your fortifications you are so proud of, and defile your Temple.

25.verse: For the time has come for the cutting off of Israel. You will sue for peace, but you won’t get it.

26.verse: Calamity upon calamity will befall you; woe upon woe, disaster upon disaster! You will long for a prophet to guide you, but the priests and elders and the kings and princes will stand helpless, weeping in despair. The people will tremble with fear, for I will do to them the evil they have done and give them all their just deserts. They shall learn that I am the Lord.”

1.verse: Then, late in August of the sixth year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity, as I was talking with the elders of Judah in my home, the power of the Lord God fell upon me.

2.verse: I saw what appeared to be a Man; from his waist down, he was made of fire; from his waist up, he was all amber-colored brightness.

3.verse: He put out what seemed to be a hand and took me by the hair. And the Spirit lifted me up into the sky and seemed to transport me to Jerusalem, to the entrance of the north gate, where the large idol was that had made the Lord so angry.

4.verse: Suddenly the glory of the God of Israel was there, just as I had seen it before in the valley.

5.verse: He said to me, “Son of dust, look toward the north.” So I looked and, sure enough, north of the altar gate in the entrance stood the idol.

6.verse: And he said: “Son of dust, do you see what they are doing? Do you see what great sins the people of Israel are doing here, to push me from my Temple? But come, and I will show you greater sins than these!”

7.verse: Then he brought me to the door of the Temple court, where I could see an opening in the wall.

8.verse: “Now dig into the wall,” he said. I did and uncovered a door to a hidden room.

9.verse: “Go in,” he said, “and see the wickedness going on in there!”

10.verse: So I went in. The walls were covered with pictures of all kinds of snakes, lizards, and hideous creatures, besides all the various idols worshiped by the people of Israel.

11.verse: Seventy elders of Israel were standing there along with Jaazaniah (son of Shaphan) worshiping the pictures. Each of them held a censer of burning incense, so there was a thick cloud of smoke above their heads.

12.verse: Then the Lord said to me: “Son of dust, have you seen what the elders of Israel are doing in their minds? For they say, ‘The Lord doesn’t see us; he has gone away!’”

13.verse: Then he added, “Come, and I will show you greater sins than these!”

14.verse: He brought me to the north gate of the Temple, and there sat women weeping for Tammuz, their god.

15.verse: “Have you seen this?” he asked. “But I will show you greater evils than these!”

16.verse: Then he brought me into the inner court of the Temple, and there at the door, between the porch and the bronze altar, were about twenty-five men standing with their backs to the Temple of the Lord, facing east, worshiping the sun!

17.verse: “Have you seen this?” he asked. “Is it nothing to the people of Judah that they commit these terrible sins, leading the whole nation into idolatry, thumbing their noses at me and arousing my fury against them?

18.verse: Therefore, I will deal with them in fury. I will neither pity nor spare. And though they scream for mercy, I will not listen.”

1.verse: Then he thundered, “Call those to whom I have given the city! Tell them to bring their weapons with them!”

2.verse: Six men appeared at his call, coming from the upper north gate, each one with his sword. One of them wore linen clothing and carried a writer’s case strapped to his side. They all went into the Temple and stood beside the bronze altar.

3.verse: And the glory of the God of Israel rose from between the Guardian Angels where it had rested and stood above the entrance to the Temple. And the Lord called to the man with the writer’s case

4.verse: and said to him, “Walk through the streets of Jerusalem and put a mark on the foreheads of the men who weep and sigh because of all the sins they see around them.”

5.verse: Then I heard the Lord tell the other men: “Follow him through the city and kill everyone whose forehead isn’t marked. Spare not nor pity them—

6.verse: kill them all—old and young, girls, women, and little children; but don’t touch anyone with the mark. And begin right here at the Temple.” And so they began by killing the seventy elders.

7.verse: And he said, “Defile the Temple! Fill its courts with the bodies of those you kill! Go!” And they went out through the city and did as they were told.

8.verse: While they were fulfilling their orders, I was alone. I fell to the ground on my face and cried out: “O Lord God! Will your fury against Jerusalem wipe out everyone left in Israel?”

9.verse: But he said to me, “The sins of the people of Israel and Judah are very great and all the land is full of murder and injustice, for they say, ‘The Lord doesn’t see it! He has gone away!’

10.verse: And so I will not spare them nor have any pity on them, and I will fully repay them for all that they have done.”

11.verse: Just then the man in linen clothing, carrying the writer’s case, reported back and said, “I have finished the work you gave me to do.”

17.verse: When the Guardian Angels stood still, so did the wheels, for the spirit of the Guardian Angels was in the wheels.

18.verse: Then the glory of the Lord moved from the door of the Temple and stood above the Guardian Angels.

19.verse: And as I watched, the Guardian Angels flew with their wheels beside them to the east gate of the Temple. And the glory of the God of Israel was above them.

20.verse: These were the living beings I had seen beneath the God of Israel beside the Chebar Canal. I knew they were the same,

21.verse: for each had four faces and four wings, with what looked like human hands under their wings.

22.verse: Their faces too were identical to the faces of those I had seen at the canal, and they traveled straight ahead, just as the others did.

1.verse: Then the Spirit lifted me and brought me over to the east gate of the Temple, where I saw twenty-five of the most prominent men of the city, including two officers, Jaazaniah (son of Azzur) and Pelatiah (son of Benaiah). Then the Spirit said to me, “Son of dust, these are the men who are responsible for all of the wicked counsel being given out in this city.

2.verse: Then the Spirit lifted me and brought me over to the east gate of the Temple, where I saw twenty-five of the most prominent men of the city, including two officers, Jaazaniah (son of Azzur) and Pelatiah (son of Benaiah). Then the Spirit said to me, “Son of dust, these are the men who are responsible for all of the wicked counsel being given out in this city.

3.verse: For they say to the people, ‘It is time to rebuild Jerusalem, for our city is an iron shield and will protect us from all harm.’

4.verse: Therefore, son of dust, prophesy against them loudly and clearly.”

5.verse: Then the Spirit of the Lord came upon me and told me to say: “The Lord says to the people of Israel: Is that what you are saying? Yes, I know it is, for I know everything you think—every thought that comes into your minds.

6.verse: You have murdered endlessly and filled your streets with the dead.”

7.verse: Therefore the Lord God says: “You think this city is an iron shield? No, it isn’t! It will not protect you. Your slain will lie within it, but you will be dragged out and slaughtered.

8.verse: I will expose you to the war you have so greatly feared, says the Lord God,

9.verse: and I will take you from Jerusalem and hand you over to foreigners who will carry out my judgments against you.

10.verse: You will be slaughtered all the way to the borders of Israel, and you will know I am the Lord.

11.verse: No, this city will not be an iron shield for you, and you safe within. I will chase you even to the borders of Israel,

12.verse: and you will know I am the Lord—you who have not obeyed me but rather have copied the nations all around you.”

13.verse: While I was still speaking and telling them this, Pelatiah (son of Benaiah) suddenly died. Then I fell to the ground on my face and cried out: “O Lord God, are you going to kill everyone in all Israel?”

14.verse: Again a message came from the Lord:

15.verse: “Son of dust, the remnant left in Jerusalem are saying about your brother exiles: ‘It is because they were so wicked that the Lord has deported them. Now the Lord has given us their land!’

16.verse: “But tell the exiles that the Lord God says: Although I have scattered you in the countries of the world, yet I will be a sanctuary to you for the time that you are there,

17.verse: and I will gather you back from the nations where you are scattered and give you the land of Israel again.

18.verse: And when you return, you will remove every trace of all this idol worship.

19.verse: I will give you one heart and a new spirit; I will take from you your hearts of stone and give you tender hearts of love for God,

20.verse: so that you can obey my laws and be my people, and I will be your God.

21.verse: But as for those now in Jerusalem who long for idols, I will repay them fully for their sins,” the Lord God says.

22.verse: Then the Guardian Angels lifted their wings and rose into the air with their wheels beside them, and the glory of the God of Israel stood above them.

23.verse: Then the glory of the Lord rose from over the city and stood above the mountain on the east side.

24.verse: Afterwards the Spirit of God carried me back again to Babylon, to the Jews in exile there. And so ended the vision of my visit to Jerusalem.

25.verse: And I told the exiles everything the Lord had shown me.

1.verse: Again a message came to me from the Lord:

2.verse: “Son of dust,” he said, “you live among rebels who could know the truth if they wanted to, but they don’t want to; they could hear me if they would listen, but they won’t,

3.verse: for they are rebels. So now put on a demonstration to show them what being exiled will be like. Pack whatever you can carry on your back and leave your home—go somewhere else. Go in the daylight so they can see, for perhaps even yet they will consider what this means, even though they are such rebels.

4.verse: Bring your baggage outside your house during the daylight so they can watch. Then leave the house at night, just as captives do when they begin their long march to distant lands.

5.verse: Dig a tunnel through the city wall while they are observing and carry your possessions out through the hole.

6.verse: As they watch, lift your pack to your shoulders and walk away into the night; muffle your face and don’t gaze around. All this is a sign to the people of Israel of the evil that will come upon Jerusalem.”

7.verse: So I did as I was told. I brought my pack outside in the daylight—all I could take into exile—and in the evening I dug through the wall with my hands. I went out into the darkness with my pack on my shoulder while the people looked on.

8.verse: The next morning this message came to me from the Lord:

9.verse: “Son of dust, these rebels, the people of Israel, have asked what all this means.

10.verse: Tell them the Lord God says it is a message to King Zedekiah in Jerusalem and to all the people of Israel.

11.verse: Explain that what you did was a demonstration of what is going to happen to them, for they shall be driven out of their homes and sent away into exile.

12.verse: “Even King Zedekiah shall go out at night through a hole in the wall, taking only what he can carry with him, with muffled face, for he won’t be able to see.

13.verse: I will capture him in my net and bring him to Babylon, the land of the Chaldeans; but he shall not see it,* and he shall die there.

14.verse: I will scatter his servants and guards to the four winds and send the sword after them.

15.verse: And when I scatter them among the nations, then they shall know I am the Lord.

16.verse: But I will spare a few of them from death by war and famine and disease. I will save them to confess to the nations how wicked they have been, and they shall know I am the Lord.”

17.verse: Then this message came to me from the Lord:

18.verse: “Son of dust, tremble as you eat your meals; ration out your water as though it were your last,

19.verse: and say to the people, the Lord God says that the people of Israel and Jerusalem shall ration their food with utmost care and sip their tiny portions of water in utter despair because of all their sins.

20.verse: Your cities shall be destroyed and your farmlands deserted, and you shall know I am the Lord.”

21.verse: Again a message came to me from the Lord:

22.verse: “Son of dust, what is that proverb they quote in Israel—‘The days as they pass make liars out of every prophet.’

23.verse: The Lord God says: I will put an end to this proverb and they will soon stop saying it. Give them this one instead: ‘The time has come for all these prophecies to be fulfilled.’

24.verse: “Then you will see what becomes of all the false predictions of safety and security for Jerusalem.

25.verse: For I am the Lord! What I threaten always happens. There will be no more delays, O rebels of Israel! I will do it in your own lifetime!” says the Lord God.

26.verse: Then this message came:

27.verse: “Son of dust, the people of Israel say, ‘His visions won’t come true for a long, long time.’

28.verse: Therefore say to them: ‘The Lord God says: All delay has ended! I will do it now!’”

1.verse: Then this message came to me:

2.verse: “Son of dust, prophesy against the false prophets of Israel who are inventing their own visions and claiming to have messages from me when I have never told them anything at all. Woe upon them!

3.verse: “Son of dust, prophesy against the false prophets of Israel who are inventing their own visions and claiming to have messages from me when I have never told them anything at all. Woe upon them!

4.verse: “O Israel, these ‘prophets’ of yours are as useless as foxes for rebuilding your walls!

5.verse: O evil prophets, what have you ever done to strengthen the walls of Israel against her enemies—by strengthening Israel in the Lord?

6.verse: Instead you have lied when you said, ‘My message is from God!’ God did not send you. And yet you expect him to fulfill your prophecies.

7.verse: Can you deny that you have claimed to see ‘visions’ you never saw, and that you have said, ‘This message is from God,’ when I never spoke to you at all?”

8.verse: Therefore the Lord God says: “I will destroy you for these ‘visions’ and lies.

9.verse: My hand shall be against you, and you shall be cut off from among the leaders of Israel; I will blot out your names, and you will never see your own country again. And you shall know I am the Lord.

10.verse: For these evil men deceive my people by saying, ‘God will send peace,’ when that is not my plan at all! My people build a flimsy wall, and these prophets praise them for it—and cover it with whitewash!

11.verse: “Tell these evil builders that their wall will fall. A heavy rainstorm will undermine it; great hailstones and mighty winds will knock it down.

12.verse: And when the wall falls, the people will cry out, ‘Why didn’t you tell us that it wasn’t good enough? Why did you whitewash it and cover up its faults?’

13.verse: Yes, it will surely fall.” The Lord God says: “I will sweep it away with a storm of indignation, with a great flood of anger, and with hailstones of wrath.

14.verse: I will break down your whitewashed wall; it will fall on you and crush you, and you shall know I am the Lord.

15.verse: Then at last my wrath against the wall will be completed; and concerning those who praised it, I will say: The wall and its builders both are gone.

16.verse: For they were lying prophets, claiming Jerusalem will have peace when there is no peace,” says the Lord God.

17.verse: “Son of dust, speak out against the women prophets too who pretend the Lord has given them his messages.

18.verse: Tell them, ‘The Lord God says: Woe to these women who are damning the souls of my people, of both young and old alike, by tying magic charms on their wrists, furnishing them with magic veils, and selling them indulgences. They refuse to even offer help unless they get a profit from it.

19.verse: For the sake of a few paltry handfuls of barley or a piece of bread will you turn away my people from me? You have led those to death who should not die! And you have promised life to those who should not live by lying to my people—and how they love it!’”

20.verse: And so the Lord says: “I will crush you because you hunt my people’s souls with all your magic charms. I will tear off the charms and set my people free like birds from cages.

21.verse: I will tear off the magic veils and save my people from you; they will no longer be your victims, and you shall know I am the Lord.

22.verse: Your lies have discouraged the righteous when I didn’t want it so. And you have encouraged the wicked by promising life, though they continue in their sins.

23.verse: But you will lie no more; no longer will you talk of seeing ‘visions’ that you never saw nor practice your magic, for I will deliver my people out of your hands by destroying you, and you shall know I am the Lord.”

1.verse: Then some of the elders of Israel visited me to ask me for a message from the Lord,

2.verse: and this is the message that came to me to give to them:

3.verse: “Son of dust, these men worship idols in their hearts—should I let them ask me anything?

4.verse: Tell them, ‘The Lord God says: I, the Lord, will personally deal with anyone in Israel who worships idols and then comes to ask my help.

5.verse: For I will punish the minds and hearts of those who turn from me to idols.’

6.verse: “Therefore, warn them that the Lord God says: ‘Repent and destroy your idols, and stop worshiping them in your hearts. I the Lord will personally punish everyone, whether people of Israel or the foreigners living among you, who rejects me for idols and then comes to a prophet to ask for my help and advice.

7.verse: “Therefore, warn them that the Lord God says: ‘Repent and destroy your idols, and stop worshiping them in your hearts. I the Lord will personally punish everyone, whether people of Israel or the foreigners living among you, who rejects me for idols and then comes to a prophet to ask for my help and advice.

8.verse: I will turn upon him and make a terrible example of him, destroying him; and you shall know I am the Lord.

9.verse: And if one of the false prophets gives him a message anyway, it is a lie. His prophecy will not come true, and I will stand against that “prophet” and destroy him from among my people Israel.

10.verse: False prophets and hypocrites—evil people who say they want my words—all will be punished for their sins,

11.verse: so that the people of Israel will learn not to desert me and not to be polluted any longer with sin. They will be my people and I their God.’ So says the Lord.”

12.verse: Then this message of the Lord came to me:

13.verse: “Son of dust, if the people of a land sin against me, then I will crush them with my fist, break off their food supply, and send famine to destroy both man and beast.

14.verse: Even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were in it, they alone would be saved by their righteousness, and I would destroy the remainder of Israel,” says the Lord God.

15.verse: “If I send an invasion of dangerous wild animals into the land to devastate the land,

16.verse: even if these three men were there, the Lord God swears that it would do no good—it would not save the people from their doom. Those three only would be saved, but the land would be devastated.

17.verse: “Or if I bring war against that land and tell the armies of the enemy to come and destroy everything,

18.verse: even if these three men were in the land, the Lord God declares that they alone would be saved.

19.verse: “And if I pour out my fury by sending an epidemic of disease into the land, and the plague kills man and beast alike,

20.verse: though Noah, Daniel, and Job were living there, the Lord God says that only they would be saved because of their righteousness.”

21.verse: And the Lord says: “Four great punishments await Jerusalem to destroy all life: war, famine, ferocious beasts, plague.

22.verse: If there are survivors and they come here to join you as exiles in Babylon, you will see with your own eyes how wicked they are, and you will know it was right for me to destroy Jerusalem.

23.verse: You will agree, when you meet them, that it is not without cause that all these things are being done to Israel.”

1.verse: Then this message came to me from the Lord:

2.verse: “Son of dust, what good are vines from the forest? Are they as useful as trees? Are they even as valuable as a single branch?

3.verse: No, for vines can’t be used even for making pegs to hang up pots and pans!

4.verse: All they are good for is fuel—and even so, they burn but poorly!

5.verse: So they are useless both before and after being put in the fire! “This is what I mean,” the Lord God says: “The people of Jerusalem are like the vines of the forest—useless before being burned and certainly useless afterwards!

6.verse: So they are useless both before and after being put in the fire! “This is what I mean,” the Lord God says: “The people of Jerusalem are like the vines of the forest—useless before being burned and certainly useless afterwards!

7.verse: And I will set myself against them to see to it that if they escape from one fire, they will fall into another; and then you shall know I am the Lord.

8.verse: And I will make the land desolate because they worship idols,” says the Lord God.

1.verse: Then again a message came to me from the Lord.

2.verse: “Son of dust,” he said, “speak to Jerusalem about her loathsome sins.

3.verse: Tell her, ‘The Lord God says: You are no better than the people of Canaan—your father must have been an Amorite and your mother a Hittite!

4.verse: When you were born, no one cared for you. When I first saw you, your umbilical cord was uncut, and you had been neither washed nor rubbed with salt nor clothed.

5.verse: No one had the slightest interest in you; no one pitied you or cared for you. On that day when you were born, you were dumped out into a field and left to die, unwanted.

6.verse: “‘But I came by and saw you there, covered with your own blood, and I said, “Live! Thrive like a plant in the field!” And you did! You grew up and became tall, slender and supple, a jewel among jewels. And when you reached the age of maidenhood, your breasts were full-formed and your pubic hair had grown; yet you were naked.

7.verse: “‘But I came by and saw you there, covered with your own blood, and I said, “Live! Thrive like a plant in the field!” And you did! You grew up and became tall, slender and supple, a jewel among jewels. And when you reached the age of maidenhood, your breasts were full-formed and your pubic hair had grown; yet you were naked.

8.verse: “‘Later, when I passed by and saw you again, you were old enough for marriage; and I wrapped my cloak around you to legally declare my marriage vow. I signed a covenant with you, and you became mine.

9.verse: Then, when the marriage had taken place, I gave you beautiful clothes of linens and silk, embroidered, and sandals made of dolphin hide.

10.verse: Then, when the marriage had taken place, I gave you beautiful clothes of linens and silk, embroidered, and sandals made of dolphin hide.

11.verse: I gave you lovely ornaments, bracelets, and beautiful necklaces,

12.verse: a ring for your nose and two more for your ears, and a lovely tiara for your head.

13.verse: And so you were made beautiful with gold and silver, and your clothes were silk and linen and beautifully embroidered. You ate the finest foods and became more beautiful than ever. You looked like a queen, and so you were!

14.verse: Your reputation was great among the nations for your beauty; it was perfect because of all the gifts I gave you,’” says the Lord God.

15.verse: “‘But you thought you could get along without me—you trusted in your beauty instead; and you gave yourself as a prostitute to every man who came along. Your beauty was his for the asking.

16.verse: You used the lovely things I gave you for making idol shrines and to decorate your bed of prostitution. Unbelievable! There has never been anything like it before!

17.verse: You took the very jewels and gold and silver ornaments I gave to you and made statues of men and worshiped them, which is adultery against me.

18.verse: You used the beautifully embroidered clothes I gave you—to cover your idols! And used my oil and incense to worship them!

19.verse: You set before them as a lovely sacrifice—imagine it—the fine flour and oil and honey I gave you!

20.verse: And you took my sons and daughters you had borne to me and sacrificed them to your gods; and they are gone. Wasn’t it enough that you should be a prostitute?

21.verse: Must you also slay my children by sacrificing them to idols?

22.verse: “‘And in all these years of adultery and sin you have not thought of those days long ago when you were naked and covered with blood.

23.verse: “‘And then, in addition to all your other wickedness—woe, woe upon you, says the Lord God—

24.verse: you built a spacious brothel for your lovers and idol altars on every street,

25.verse: and there you offered your beauty to every man who came by, in an endless stream of prostitution.

26.verse: And you added lustful Egypt to your prostitutions by your alliance with her. My anger is great.

27.verse: “‘Therefore I have crushed you with my fist; I have reduced your boundaries and delivered you into the hands of those who hate you—the Philistines—and even they are ashamed of you.

28.verse: “‘You have committed adultery with the Assyrians too by making them your allies and worshiping their gods; it seems that you can never find enough new gods. After your adultery there, you still weren’t satisfied,

29.verse: so you worshiped the gods of that great merchant land of Babylon—and you still weren’t satisfied.

30.verse: What a filthy heart you have, says the Lord God, to do such things as these; you are a brazen prostitute,

31.verse: building your idol altars, your brothels, on every street. You have been worse than a prostitute, so eager for sin that you have not even charged for your love!

32.verse: Yes, you are an adulterous wife who lives with other men instead of her own husband.

33.verse: Prostitutes charge for their services—men pay with many gifts. But not you, you give them gifts, bribing them to come to you! So you are different from other prostitutes. But you had to pay them, for no one wanted you.

34.verse: Prostitutes charge for their services—men pay with many gifts. But not you, you give them gifts, bribing them to come to you! So you are different from other prostitutes. But you had to pay them, for no one wanted you.

35.verse: “‘O prostitute, hear the word of the Lord:

36.verse: This is what the Lord God says! Because I see your filthy sins, your adultery with your lovers—your worshiping of idols—and the slaying of your children as sacrifices to your gods,

37.verse: this is what I am going to do: I will gather together all your allies—these lovers of yours you have sinned with, both those you loved and those you hated—and I will make you naked before them that they may see you.

38.verse: I will punish you as a murderess is punished and as a woman breaking wedlock living with other men.

39.verse: I will give you to your lovers—these many nations—to destroy, and they will knock down your brothels and idol altars. They will strip you, take your beautiful jewels, and leave you naked and ashamed.

40.verse: They will burn your homes, punishing you before the eyes of many women. And I will see to it that you stop your adulteries with other gods and end your payments to your allies for their love.

41.verse: They will burn your homes, punishing you before the eyes of many women. And I will see to it that you stop your adulteries with other gods and end your payments to your allies for their love.

42.verse: “‘Then at last my fury against you will die away; my jealousy against you will end, and I will be quiet and not be angry with you anymore.

43.verse: But first, because you have not remembered your youth but have angered me by all these evil things you do, I will fully repay you for all of your sins,’” says the Lord. “‘For you are thankless in addition to all your other faults.

44.verse: “‘“Like mother, like daughter”—that is what everyone will say of you.

45.verse: For your mother loathed her husband and her children, and you do too. And you are exactly like your sisters, for they despised their husbands and their children. Truly, your mother must have been a Hittite and your father an Amorite.

46.verse: “‘Your older sister is Samaria, living with her daughters north of you; your younger sister is Sodom and her daughters, in the south.

47.verse: You have not merely sinned as they do—no, that was nothing to you; in a very short time you far surpassed them.

48.verse: “‘As I live, the Lord God says, Sodom and her daughters have never been as wicked as you and your daughters.

49.verse: Your sister Sodom’s sins were pride, laziness, and too much food, while the poor and needy suffered outside her door.

50.verse: She insolently worshiped many idols as I watched. Therefore I crushed her.

51.verse: “‘Even Samaria has not committed half your sins. You have worshiped idols far more than your sisters have; they seem almost righteous in comparison with you!

52.verse: Don’t be surprised then by the lighter punishment they get. For your sins are so awful that in comparison with you, your sisters seem innocent!

53.verse: (But someday I will restore the fortunes of Sodom and Samaria again, and those of Judah too.)

54.verse: Your terrible punishment will be a consolation to them, for it will be greater than theirs.

55.verse: “‘Yes, your sisters, Sodom and Samaria, and all their people will be restored again, and Judah, too, will prosper in that day.

56.verse: In your proud days you held Sodom in unspeakable contempt.

57.verse: But now your greater wickedness has been exposed to all the world, and you are the one who is scorned—by Edom and all her neighbors and by all the Philistines.

58.verse: This is part of your punishment for all your sins,’” says the Lord.

59.verse: For the Lord God says: “I will repay you for your broken promises. You lightly broke your solemn vows to me, yet I will keep the pledge I made to you when you were young. I will establish an everlasting covenant with you forever,

60.verse: For the Lord God says: “I will repay you for your broken promises. You lightly broke your solemn vows to me, yet I will keep the pledge I made to you when you were young. I will establish an everlasting covenant with you forever,

61.verse: and you will remember with shame all the evil you have done; and you will be overcome by my favor when I take your sisters, Samaria and Sodom, and make them your daughters, for you to rule over. You will know you don’t deserve this gracious act, for you did not keep my covenant.

62.verse: I will reaffirm my covenant with you, and you will know I am the Lord.

63.verse: Despite all you have done, I will be kind to you again; you will cover your mouth in silence and in shame when I forgive you all that you have done,” says the Lord God.

1.verse: Then this message came to me from the Lord:

2.verse: “Son of dust, give this riddle to the people of Israel:

3.verse: “A great eagle with broad wings full of many-colored feathers came to Lebanon and plucked off the shoot at the top of the tallest cedar tree and carried it into a city filled with merchants.

4.verse: “A great eagle with broad wings full of many-colored feathers came to Lebanon and plucked off the shoot at the top of the tallest cedar tree and carried it into a city filled with merchants.

5.verse: There he planted it in fertile ground beside a broad river, where it would grow as quickly as a willow tree.

6.verse: It took root and grew and became a low but spreading vine that turned toward the eagle and produced strong branches and luxuriant leaves.

7.verse: But when another great, broad-winged, full-feathered eagle came along, this tree sent its roots and branches out toward him instead,

8.verse: even though it was already in good soil with plenty of water to become a splendid vine, producing leaves and fruit.”

9.verse: The Lord God asks: “Shall I let this tree grow and prosper? No! I will pull it out, roots and all! I will cut off its branches and let its leaves wither and die. It will pull out easily enough—it won’t take a big crew or a lot of equipment to do that.

10.verse: Though the vine began so well, will it thrive? No, it will wither away completely when the east wind touches it, dying in the same choice soil where it had grown so well.”

11.verse: Then this message came to me from the Lord:

12.verse: “Ask these rebels of Israel: Don’t you understand what this riddle of the eagles means? I will tell you. Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon (the first of the two eagles), came to Jerusalem, took away her king and princes (her topmost buds and shoots),* and brought them to Babylon. Nebuchadnezzar made a covenant with a member of the royal family (Zedekiah),* and made him take an oath of loyalty. He took a seedling and planted it in fertile ground beside a broad river. He also exiled the top men of Israel’s government,

13.verse: “Ask these rebels of Israel: Don’t you understand what this riddle of the eagles means? I will tell you. Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon (the first of the two eagles), came to Jerusalem, took away her king and princes (her topmost buds and shoots),* and brought them to Babylon. Nebuchadnezzar made a covenant with a member of the royal family (Zedekiah),* and made him take an oath of loyalty. He took a seedling and planted it in fertile ground beside a broad river. He also exiled the top men of Israel’s government,

14.verse: so that Israel would not be strong again and revolt. But by keeping her promises, Israel could be respected and maintain her identity.

15.verse: “Nevertheless, Zedekiah rebelled against Babylon, sending ambassadors to Egypt to seek for a great army and many horses to fight against Nebuchadnezzar. But will Israel prosper after breaking all her promises like that? Will she succeed?

16.verse: No! For as I live,” says the Lord, “the king of Israel shall die. (Nebuchadnezzar will pull out the tree, roots and all!) Zedekiah* shall die in Babylon, where the king lives who gave him his power, and whose covenant he despised and broke.

17.verse: Pharaoh and all his mighty army shall fail to help Israel when the king of Babylon lays siege to Jerusalem again and slaughters many lives.

18.verse: For the king of Israel broke his promise after swearing to obey; therefore he shall not escape.”

19.verse: The Lord God says: “As I live, surely I will punish him for despising the solemn oath he made in my name.

20.verse: I will throw my net over him, and he shall be captured in my snare; I will bring him to Babylon and deal with him there for this treason against me.

21.verse: And all the best soldiers of Israel will be killed by the sword, and those remaining in the city will be scattered to the four winds. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have spoken these words.”

22.verse: The Lord God says: “I will take a tender sprout from the top of a tall cedar, and I will plant it on the top of Israel’s highest mountain. It shall become a noble cedar, bringing forth branches and bearing seed. Animals of every sort will gather under it; its branches will shelter every kind of bird.

23.verse: The Lord God says: “I will take a tender sprout from the top of a tall cedar, and I will plant it on the top of Israel’s highest mountain. It shall become a noble cedar, bringing forth branches and bearing seed. Animals of every sort will gather under it; its branches will shelter every kind of bird.

24.verse: And everyone shall know that it is I, the Lord, who cuts down the high trees and exalts the low, that I make the green tree wither and the dead tree grow. I, the Lord, have said that I would do it, and I will.”

1.verse: Then the Lord’s message came to me again.

2.verse: “Why do people use this proverb about the land of Israel: The children are punished for their fathers’ sins?

3.verse: As I live,” says the Lord God, “you will not use this proverb anymore in Israel,

4.verse: for all souls are mine to judge—fathers and sons alike—and my rule is this: It is for a man’s own sins that he will die.

5.verse: “But if a man is just and does what is lawful and right,

6.verse: and has not gone out to the mountains to feast before the idols of Israel and worship them, and does not commit adultery nor lie with any woman during the time of her menstruation;

7.verse: if he is a merciful creditor, not holding onto the items given to him in pledge by poor debtors, and is no robber but gives food to the hungry and clothes to those in need;

8.verse: and if he grants loans without interest, stays away from sin, is honest and fair when judging others,

9.verse: and obeys my laws—that man is just,” says the Lord, “and he shall surely live.

10.verse: “But if that man has a son who is a robber or murderer and who fulfills none of his responsibilities,

11.verse: who refuses to obey the laws of God but worships idols on the mountains and commits adultery,

12.verse: oppresses the poor and helpless, robs his debtors by refusing to let them redeem what they have given him in pledge, loves idols and worships them,

13.verse: and loans out his money at interest—shall that man live? No! He shall surely die, and it is his own fault.

14.verse: “But if this sinful man has, in turn, a son who sees all his father’s wickedness, so that he fears God and decides against that kind of life;

15.verse: he doesn’t go up on the mountains to feast before the idols and worship them and does not commit adultery;

16.verse: he is fair to those who borrow from him and doesn’t rob them, but feeds the hungry, clothes the needy,

17.verse: helps the poor, does not loan money at interest, and obeys my laws—he shall not die because of his father’s sins; he shall surely live.

18.verse: But his father shall die for his own sins because he is cruel and robs and does wrong.

19.verse: “‘What?’ you ask. ‘Doesn’t the son pay for his father’s sins?’ No! For if the son does what is right and keeps my laws, he shall surely live.

20.verse: The one who sins is the one who dies. The son shall not be punished for his father’s sins, nor the father for his son’s. The righteous person will be rewarded for his own goodness and the wicked person for his wickedness.

21.verse: But if a wicked person turns away from all his sins and begins to obey my laws and do what is just and right, he shall surely live and not die.

22.verse: All his past sins will be forgotten, and he shall live because of his goodness.

23.verse: “Do you think I like to see the wicked die?” asks the Lord. “Of course not! I only want him to turn from his wicked ways and live.

24.verse: However, if a righteous person turns to sinning and acts like any other sinner, should he be allowed to live? No, of course not. All his previous goodness will be forgotten and he shall die for his sins.

25.verse: “Yet you say: ‘The Lord isn’t being fair!’ Listen to me, O people of Israel. Am I the one who is unfair, or is it you?

26.verse: When a good man turns away from being good, begins sinning, and dies in his sins, he dies for the evil he has done.

27.verse: And if a wicked person turns away from his wickedness and obeys the law and does right, he shall save his soul,

28.verse: for he has thought it over and decided to turn from his sins and live a good life. He shall surely live—he shall not die.

29.verse: “And yet the people of Israel keep saying: ‘The Lord is unfair!’ O people of Israel, it is you who are unfair, not I.

30.verse: I will judge each of you, O Israel, and punish or reward each according to his own actions. Oh, turn from your sins while there is yet time.

31.verse: Put them behind you and receive a new heart and a new spirit. For why will you die, O Israel?

32.verse: I do not enjoy seeing you die,” the Lord God says. “Turn, turn and live!

1.verse: “Sing this death dirge for the leaders of Israel:

2.verse: What a woman your mother was—like a lioness! Her children were like lion’s cubs!

3.verse: One of her cubs, King Jehoahaz, grew into a strong young lion and learned to catch prey and became a man-eater.

4.verse: Then the nations called out their hunters; they trapped him in a pit and brought him in chains to Egypt.

5.verse: “When Israel, the mother lion, saw that all her hopes for him were gone, she took another of her cubs, King Jehoiachin, and taught him to be ‘king of the beasts.’

6.verse: He became a leader among the lions and learned to catch prey, and he too became a man-eater.

7.verse: He demolished the palaces of the surrounding nations and ruined their cities; their farms were desolated, their crops destroyed; everyone in the land shook with terror when they heard him roar.

8.verse: Then the armies of the nations surrounded him, coming from every side, and trapped him in a pit and captured him.

9.verse: They prodded him into a cage and brought him before the king of Babylon. He was held in captivity so that his voice could never again be heard upon the mountains of Israel.

10.verse: “Your mother was like a vine beside an irrigation ditch, with lush, green foliage because of all the water.

11.verse: Its strongest branch became a ruler’s scepter, and it was very great, towering above the others and noticed from far away.

12.verse: But the vine was uprooted in fury and thrown down to the ground. Its branches were broken and withered by a strong wind from the east; the fruit was destroyed by fire.

13.verse: Now the vine is planted in the wilderness where the ground is hard and dry.

14.verse: It is decaying from within; no strong branch remains. The fulfillment of this sad prophecy has already begun, and there is more ahead.”

1.verse: Late in July, six years after King Jeconiah was captured, some of the elders of Israel came to ask instructions from the Lord and sat before me awaiting his reply.

2.verse: Then the Lord gave me this message:

3.verse: “Son of dust, say to the elders of Israel, ‘The Lord God says: How dare you come to ask my help? I swear that I will tell you nothing.’

4.verse: Judge them, son of dust; condemn them; tell them of all the sins of this nation from the times of their fathers until now.

5.verse: Tell them, ‘The Lord God says: When I chose Israel and revealed myself to her in Egypt, I swore to her and her descendants that I would bring them out of Egypt to a land I had discovered and explored for them—a good land, flowing as it were with milk and honey, the best of all lands anywhere.’

6.verse: Tell them, ‘The Lord God says: When I chose Israel and revealed myself to her in Egypt, I swore to her and her descendants that I would bring them out of Egypt to a land I had discovered and explored for them—a good land, flowing as it were with milk and honey, the best of all lands anywhere.’

7.verse: “Then I said to them: ‘Get rid of every idol; do not defile yourselves with the Egyptian gods, for I am the Lord your God.’

8.verse: But they rebelled against me and would not listen. They didn’t get rid of their idols nor forsake the gods of Egypt. Then I thought, I will pour out my fury upon them and fulfill my anger against them while they are still in Egypt.

9.verse: “But I didn’t do it, for I acted to protect the honor of my name, lest the Egyptians laugh at Israel’s God who couldn’t keep them from harm. So I brought my people out of Egypt right before the Egyptians’ eyes and led them into the wilderness.

10.verse: “But I didn’t do it, for I acted to protect the honor of my name, lest the Egyptians laugh at Israel’s God who couldn’t keep them from harm. So I brought my people out of Egypt right before the Egyptians’ eyes and led them into the wilderness.

11.verse: There I gave them my laws so they could live by keeping them. If anyone keeps them, he will live.

12.verse: And I gave them the Sabbath—a day of rest every seventh day—as a symbol between them and me, to remind them that it is I, the Lord, who sanctifies them—that they are truly my people.

13.verse: “But Israel rebelled against me. There in the wilderness they refused my laws. They would not obey my rules even though obeying them means life. And they misused my Sabbaths. Then I thought, I will pour out my fury upon them and utterly consume them in the desert.

14.verse: “But again I refrained in order to protect the honor of my name, lest the nations who saw me bring them out of Egypt would say that it was because I couldn’t care for them that I destroyed them.

15.verse: But I swore to them in the wilderness that I would not bring them into the land I had given them, a land full of milk and honey, the choicest spot on earth,

16.verse: because they laughed at my laws, ignored my wishes, and violated my Sabbaths—their hearts were with their idols!

17.verse: Nevertheless, I spared them. I didn’t finish them off in the wilderness.

18.verse: “Then I spoke to their children and said: ‘Don’t follow your fathers’ footsteps. Don’t defile yourselves with their idols,

19.verse: for I am the Lord your God. Follow my laws; keep my ordinances;

20.verse: hallow my Sabbaths; for they are a symbol of the contract between us to help you remember that I am the Lord your God.’

21.verse: “But their children, too, rebelled against me. They refused my laws—the laws that if a person keeps them, he will live. And they defiled my Sabbaths. So then I said: ‘Now at last I will pour out my fury upon you in the wilderness.’

22.verse: “Nevertheless, again I withdrew my judgment against them to protect my name among the nations who had seen my power in bringing them out of Egypt.

23.verse: But I took a solemn oath against them while they were in the wilderness that I would scatter them, dispersing them to the ends of the earth because they did not obey my laws but scorned them and violated my Sabbaths and longed for their fathers’ idols.

24.verse: But I took a solemn oath against them while they were in the wilderness that I would scatter them, dispersing them to the ends of the earth because they did not obey my laws but scorned them and violated my Sabbaths and longed for their fathers’ idols.

25.verse: I let them adopt customs and laws which were worthless. Through the keeping of them they could not attain life.*

26.verse: In the hope that they would draw back in horror and know that I alone am God, I let them pollute themselves with the very gifts I gave them. They burnt their firstborn children as offerings to their gods!

27.verse: “Son of dust, tell them that the Lord God says: Your fathers continued to blaspheme and betray me when I brought them into the land I promised them, for they offered sacrifices and incense on every high hill and under every tree! They roused my fury as they offered up their sacrifices to those ‘gods.’ They brought their perfumes and incense and poured out their drink offerings to them!

28.verse: “Son of dust, tell them that the Lord God says: Your fathers continued to blaspheme and betray me when I brought them into the land I promised them, for they offered sacrifices and incense on every high hill and under every tree! They roused my fury as they offered up their sacrifices to those ‘gods.’ They brought their perfumes and incense and poured out their drink offerings to them!

29.verse: I said to them: ‘What is this place of sacrifice where you go?’ And so it is still called ‘The Place of Sacrifice’—that is how it got its name.

30.verse: “The Lord God wants to know whether you are going to pollute yourselves just as your fathers did and keep on worshiping idols.

31.verse: For when you offer gifts to them and give your little sons to be burned to ashes as you do even today, shall I listen to you or help you, Israel? As I live,” the Lord God says, “I will not give you any message, though you have come to me to ask.

32.verse: “What you have in mind will not be done—to be like the nations all around you, serving gods of wood and stone.

33.verse: I will rule you with an iron fist and in great anger and with power.

34.verse: With might and fury I will bring you out from the lands where you are scattered,

35.verse: and will bring you into my desert judgment hall. I will judge you there and get rid of the rebels, just as I did in the wilderness after I brought you out of Egypt.

36.verse: and will bring you into my desert judgment hall. I will judge you there and get rid of the rebels, just as I did in the wilderness after I brought you out of Egypt.

37.verse: I will count you carefully and let only a small quota return.

38.verse: And the others—the rebels and all those who sin against me—I will purge from among you. They shall not enter Israel, but I will bring them out of the countries where they are in exile. And when that happens, you will know I am the Lord.

39.verse: “O Israel,” the Lord God says: “If you insist on worshiping your idols, go right ahead, but then don’t bring your gifts to me as well! Such desecration of my holy name must stop!

40.verse: “For at Jerusalem in my holy mountain,” says the Lord, “all Israel shall worship me. There I will accept you and require you to bring me your offerings and the finest of your gifts.

41.verse: You will be to me as an offering of perfumed incense when I bring you back from exile, and the nations will see the great change in your hearts.

42.verse: Then, when I have brought you home to the land I promised your fathers, you will know I am the Lord.

43.verse: Then you will look back at all your sins and loathe yourselves because of the evil you have done.

44.verse: And when I have honored my name by blessing you despite your wickedness, then, O Israel, you will know I am the Lord.”

45.verse: Then this message came to me from the Lord:

46.verse: “Son of dust, look toward Jerusalem and speak out against it and the forest lands of the Negeb.

47.verse: Prophesy to it and say: ‘Hear the word of the Lord. I will set you on fire, O forest, and every tree will die, green and dry alike. The terrible flames will not be quenched, and they will scorch the world.

48.verse: And all the world will see that I, the Lord, have set the fire. It shall not be put out.’”

49.verse: Then I said, “O Lord God, they say of me, ‘He only talks in riddles!’”

1.verse: Then this message came to me from the Lord:

2.verse: “Son of dust, face toward Jerusalem and prophesy against Israel and against my Temple!

3.verse: For the Lord says: ‘I am against you, Israel. I will unsheath my sword and destroy your people, good and bad alike—

4.verse: I will not spare even the righteous. I will make a clean sweep throughout the land from the Negeb to your northern borders.

5.verse: All the world shall know that it is I, the Lord. His sword is in his hand, and it will not return to its sheath again until its work is finished.’

6.verse: “Sigh and groan before the people, son of dust, in your bitter anguish; sigh with grief and broken heart.

7.verse: When they ask you why, tell them: ‘Because of the fearsome news that God has given me. When it comes true, the boldest heart will melt with fear; all strength will disappear. Every spirit will faint; strong knees will tremble and become as weak as water.’ And the Lord God says: ‘Your doom is on the way; my judgments will be fulfilled!’”

8.verse: Then again this message came to me from God:

9.verse: “Son of dust, tell them this: ‘A sword is being sharpened and polished for terrible slaughter. Now will you laugh? For those far stronger than you have perished beneath its power. It is ready now to hand to the executioner.’

10.verse: “Son of dust, tell them this: ‘A sword is being sharpened and polished for terrible slaughter. Now will you laugh? For those far stronger than you have perished beneath its power. It is ready now to hand to the executioner.’

11.verse: “Son of dust, tell them this: ‘A sword is being sharpened and polished for terrible slaughter. Now will you laugh? For those far stronger than you have perished beneath its power. It is ready now to hand to the executioner.’

12.verse: Son of dust, with sobbing, beat upon your thigh, for that sword shall slay my people and all their leaders. All alike shall die.

13.verse: It will put them all to the test—and what chance do they have?” the Lord God asks.

14.verse: “Prophesy to them in this way: Clap your hands vigorously, then take a sword and brandish it twice, thrice, to symbolize the great massacre they face!

15.verse: Let their hearts melt with terror, for a sword glitters at every gate; it flashes like lightning; it is razor-edged for slaughter.

16.verse: O sword, slash to the right and slash to the left, wherever you will, wherever you want.

17.verse: And you have prophesied with clapping hands that I, the Lord, will smite Jerusalem and satisfy my fury.”

18.verse: Then this message came to me. The Lord said:

19.verse: “Son of dust, make a map and on it trace two routes for the king of Babylon to follow—one to Jerusalem and the other to Rabbah in Transjordan. And put a signpost at the fork in the road from Babylon.

20.verse: “Son of dust, make a map and on it trace two routes for the king of Babylon to follow—one to Jerusalem and the other to Rabbah in Transjordan. And put a signpost at the fork in the road from Babylon.

21.verse: For the king of Babylon stands at a fork, uncertain whether to attack Jerusalem or Rabbah. He will call his magicians to use divination; they will cast lots by shaking arrows from the quiver; they will sacrifice to idols and inspect the liver of their sacrifice.

22.verse: They will decide to turn toward Jerusalem! With battering rams they will go against the gates, shouting for the kill; they will build siege towers and make a hill against the walls to reach the top.

23.verse: Jerusalem won’t understand this treachery; how could the diviners make this terrible mistake? For Babylon is Judah’s ally and has sworn to defend Jerusalem! But the king of Babylon will think only of the times the people rebelled. He will attack and defeat them.”

24.verse: The Lord God says: “Again and again your guilt cries out against you, for your sins are open and unashamed. Wherever you go, whatever you do, all is filled with sin. And now the time of punishment has come.

25.verse: “O King Zedekiah, evil prince of Israel, your final day of reckoning is here.

26.verse: Take off your jeweled crown,” the Lord God says. “The old order changes. Now the poor are exalted and the rich brought very low.

27.verse: I will overturn, overturn, overturn the kingdom, so that even the new order that emerges will not succeed until the Man appears who has a right to it. And I will give it all to him.

28.verse: “Son of dust, prophesy to the Ammonites too, for they mocked my people in their woe. Tell them this: “‘Against you also my glittering sword is drawn from its sheath; it is sharpened and polished and flashes like lightning.

29.verse: Your magicians and false prophets have told you lies of safety and success—that your gods will save you from the king of Babylon. Thus they have caused your death along with all the other wicked, for when the day of final reckoning has come, you will be wounded unto death.

30.verse: Shall I return my sword to its sheath before I deal with you? No, I will destroy you in your own country where you were born.

31.verse: I will pour out my fury upon you and blow upon the fire of my wrath until it becomes a roaring conflagration, and I will deliver you into the hands of cruel men skilled in destruction.

32.verse: You are the fuel for the fire; your blood will be spilled in your own country, and you will be utterly wiped out, your memory lost in history. For I, the Lord, have spoken it.’”

1.verse: Now another message came from the Lord. He said:

2.verse: “Son of dust, indict Jerusalem as the City of Murder. Publicly denounce her terrible deeds.

3.verse: City of Murder, doomed and damned—City of Idols, filthy and foul—

4.verse: you are guilty both of murder and idolatry. Now comes your day of doom. You have reached the limit of your years. I will make you a laughingstock and a reproach to all the nations of the world.

5.verse: Near and far they will mock you, a city of infamous rebels.

6.verse: “Every leader in Israel who lives within your walls is bent on murder.

7.verse: Fathers and mothers are contemptuously ignored; immigrants and visitors are forced to pay you for your ‘protection’; orphans and widows are wronged and oppressed.

8.verse: The things of God are all despised; my Sabbaths are ignored.

9.verse: Prisoners are falsely accused and sent to their death. Every mountaintop is filled with idols; lewdness is everywhere.

10.verse: There are men who commit adultery with their fathers’ wives and lie with menstruous women.

11.verse: Adultery with a neighbor’s wife, a daughter-in-law, a half sister—this is common.

12.verse: Hired murderers, loan racketeers, and extortioners are everywhere. You never even think of me and my commands,” the Lord God says.

13.verse: “But now I snap my fingers and call a halt to your dishonest gain and bloodshed.

14.verse: How strong and courageous will you be then, in my day of reckoning? For I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will do all that I have said.

15.verse: I will scatter you throughout the world and burn out the wickedness within you.

16.verse: You will be dishonored among the nations, and you shall know I am the Lord.”

17.verse: Then the Lord said this:

18.verse: “Son of dust, the people of Israel are the worthless slag left when silver is smelted. They are the dross, compounded from the brass, the tin, the iron, and the lead. Therefore the Lord God says: ‘Because you are worthless dross, I will bring you to my crucible in Jerusalem, to smelt you with the heat of my wrath.

19.verse: “Son of dust, the people of Israel are the worthless slag left when silver is smelted. They are the dross, compounded from the brass, the tin, the iron, and the lead. Therefore the Lord God says: ‘Because you are worthless dross, I will bring you to my crucible in Jerusalem, to smelt you with the heat of my wrath.

20.verse: “Son of dust, the people of Israel are the worthless slag left when silver is smelted. They are the dross, compounded from the brass, the tin, the iron, and the lead. Therefore the Lord God says: ‘Because you are worthless dross, I will bring you to my crucible in Jerusalem, to smelt you with the heat of my wrath.

21.verse: I will blow the fire of my wrath upon you,

22.verse: and you will melt like silver in fierce heat, and you will know that I, the Lord, have poured my wrath upon you.’”

23.verse: Again the message of the Lord came to me, saying:

24.verse: “Son of dust, say to the people of Israel: ‘In the day of my indignation you shall be like an uncleared wilderness or a desert without rain.’

25.verse: Your ‘prophets’ have plotted against you like lions stalking prey. They devour many lives; they seize treasures and extort wealth; they multiply the widows in the land.

26.verse: Your priests have violated my laws and defiled my Temple and my holiness. To them the things of God are no more important than any daily task. They have not taught my people the difference between right and wrong, and they disregard my Sabbaths, so my holy name is greatly defiled among them.

27.verse: Your leaders are like wolves, who tear apart their victims, and they destroy lives for profit.

28.verse: Your ‘prophets’ describe false visions and speak false messages they claim are from God, when he hasn’t spoken one word to them at all. Thus they repair the walls with whitewash!

29.verse: Even the common people oppress and rob the poor and needy and cruelly extort from aliens.

30.verse: “I looked in vain for anyone who would build again the wall of righteousness that guards the land, who could stand in the gap and defend you from my just attacks, but I found not one.”

31.verse: And so the Lord God says: “I will pour out my anger upon you; I will consume you with the fire of my wrath. I have heaped upon you the full penalty for all your sins.”

1.verse: The Lord’s message came to me again, saying:

2.verse: “Son of dust, there were two sisters who as young girls became prostitutes in Egypt.

3.verse: “Son of dust, there were two sisters who as young girls became prostitutes in Egypt.
