13.verse: Then he measured the entire outside width of the passageway, measuring across the roof from the outside doors of the guardrooms; this distance was 43¾ feet.

14.verse: Then he estimated the pillars on each side of the porch to be about 100 feet high.

15.verse: The full length of the entrance passage was 87½ feet from one end to the other.

16.verse: There were windows that narrowed inward through the walls along both sides of the passageway and along the guardroom walls. The windows were also in the exit and in the entrance halls. The pillars were decorated with palm tree decorations.

17.verse: And so we passed through the passageway to the court inside. A stone pavement ran around the inside of the walls, and thirty rooms were built against the walls, opening onto this pavement.

18.verse: This was called “the lower pavement.” It extended out from the walls into the court the same distance as the passageway did.

19.verse: Then he measured across to the wall on the other side of this court (which was called “the outer court” of the Temple) and found that the distance was 175 feet.

20.verse: As I followed, he left the eastern passageway and went over to the passage through the northern wall and measured it.

21.verse: Here, too, there were three guardrooms on each side, and all the measurements were the same as for the east passageway—87½ feet long and 43¾ feet from side to side across the top of the guardrooms.

22.verse: There were windows, an entry hall, and the palm tree decorations just the same as on the east side. And there were seven steps leading up to the doorway to the entry hall inside.

23.verse: Here at the north entry, just as at the east, if one walked through the passageway into the court and straight across it, he came to an inner wall and a passageway through it to an inner court. The distance between the two passageways was 175 feet.

24.verse: Then he took me around to the south gate and measured the various sections of its passageway and found they were just the same as in the others.

25.verse: It had windows along the walls as the others did, and an entry hall. And like the others, it was 87½ feet long and 43¾ feet wide.

26.verse: It, too, had a stairway of seven steps leading up to it, and there were palm tree decorations along the walls.

27.verse: And here again, if one walked through the passageway into the court and straight across it, he came to the inner wall and a passageway through it to the inner court. And the distance between the passageways was 175 feet.

28.verse: Then he took me over to the inner wall and its south passageway. He measured this passageway and found that it had the same measurements as the passageways of the outer wall.

29.verse: Its guardrooms, pillars, and entrance and exit hall were identical to all the others, and so were the windows along its walls and entry. And, like the others, it was 87½ feet long by 43¾ feet wide.

30.verse: Its guardrooms, pillars, and entrance and exit hall were identical to all the others, and so were the windows along its walls and entry. And, like the others, it was 87½ feet long by 43¾ feet wide.

31.verse: The only difference was that it had eight steps leading up to it instead of seven. It had palm tree decorations on the pillars, just as the others.

32.verse: Then he took me along the court to the eastern entrance of the inner wall, and measured it. It, too, had the same measurements as the others.

33.verse: Its guardrooms, pillars, and entrance hall were the same size as those of the other passageways, and there were windows along the walls and in the entry hall; and it was 87½ feet long by 43¾ feet wide.

34.verse: Its entry hall faced the outer court, and there were palm tree decorations on its columns, but there were eight steps instead of seven going up to the entrance.

35.verse: Then he took me around to the north gate of the inner wall, and the measurements there were just like the others:

36.verse: The guardrooms, pillars, and entry hall of this passageway were the same as the others, with a length of 87½ feet and a width of 43¾ feet.

37.verse: Its entry hall faced toward the outer court; it had palm tree decorations on the walls of each side of the passageway, and there were eight steps leading up to the entrance.

38.verse: But a door led from its entry hall into a side room where the flesh of the sacrifices was washed before being taken to the altar;

39.verse: on each side of the entry hall of the passageway there were two tables where the animals for sacrifice were slaughtered for the burnt offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings to be presented in the Temple.

40.verse: Outside the entry hall, on each side of the stairs going up to the north entrance, there were two more tables.

41.verse: So, in all there were eight tables, four inside and four outside, where the sacrifices were cut up and prepared.

42.verse: There were also four stone tables where the butchering knives and other implements were laid. These tables were about 2⅝ feet square and 1¾ feet high.

43.verse: There were hooks, 3 or 4 inches long, fastened along the walls of the entry hall, and on the tables the flesh of the offering was to be laid.

44.verse: In the inner court there were two one-room buildings, one beside the northern entrance, facing south, and one beside the southern entrance, facing north.

45.verse: And he said to me: “The building beside the inner northern gate is for the priests who supervise the maintenance.

46.verse: The building beside the inner southern entrance is for the priests in charge of the altar—the descendants of Zadok—for they alone of all the Levites may come near to the Lord to minister to him.”

47.verse: Then he measured the inner court in front of the Temple and found it to be 175 feet square, and there was an altar in the court, standing in front of the Temple.

48.verse: Then he brought me to the entrance hall of the Temple. Ten steps led up to it from the inner court. Its walls extended up on either side to form two pillars, each of them 8¾ feet thick. The entrance was 24½ feet wide with 5¼-foot walls. Thus the entry hall was 35 feet wide and 19¼ feet long.

49.verse: Then he brought me to the entrance hall of the Temple. Ten steps led up to it from the inner court. Its walls extended up on either side to form two pillars, each of them 8¾ feet thick. The entrance was 24½ feet wide with 5¼-foot walls. Thus the entry hall was 35 feet wide and 19¼ feet long.

1.verse: Afterward he brought me into the nave, the large main room of the Temple, and measured the pillars that formed its doorway. They were 10½ feet square.

2.verse: The entrance hall was 17½ feet wide and 8¾ feet deep. The nave itself was 70 feet long by 35 feet.

3.verse: Then he went into the inner room at the end of the nave and measured the columns at the entrance and found them to be 3½ feet thick; its doorway was 10½ feet wide, with a hallway 12¼ feet deep behind it.

4.verse: The inner room was 35 feet square. “This,” he told me, “is the Most Holy Place.”

5.verse: Then he measured the wall of the Temple and found that it was 10½ feet thick, with a row of rooms along the outside. Each room was 7 feet wide.

6.verse: These rooms were in three tiers, one above the other, with thirty rooms in each tier. The whole structure was supported by girders and not attached to the Temple wall for support.

7.verse: Each tier was wider than the one below it, corresponding to the narrowing of the Temple wall as it rose higher. A stairway at the side of the Temple led up from floor to floor.

8.verse: I noticed that the Temple was built on a terrace and that the bottom row of rooms extended out 10½ feet onto the terrace.

9.verse: The outer wall of these rooms was 8¾ feet thick, leaving a free space of 8¾ feet out to the edge of the terrace, the same on both sides.

10.verse: Thirty-five feet away from the terrace, on both sides of the Temple, was another row of rooms down in the inner court.

11.verse: Two doors opened from the tiers of rooms to the terrace yard, which was 8¾ feet wide; one door faced north and the other south.

12.verse: A large building stood on the west, facing the Temple yard, measuring 122½ feet wide by 157½ feet long. Its walls were 8¾ feet thick.

13.verse: Then he measured the Temple and its immediately surrounding yards. The area was 175 feet square.

14.verse: The inner court at the east of the Temple was also 175 feet wide,

15.verse: and so was the building west of the Temple, including its two walls. The nave of the Temple and the Holy of Holies and the entry hall were paneled, and all three had recessed windows. The inner walls of the Temple were paneled with wood above and below the windows.

16.verse: and so was the building west of the Temple, including its two walls. The nave of the Temple and the Holy of Holies and the entry hall were paneled, and all three had recessed windows. The inner walls of the Temple were paneled with wood above and below the windows.

17.verse: The space above the door leading into the Holy of Holies was also paneled. The walls were decorated with carvings of Guardian Angels, each with two faces, and of palm trees alternating with the Guardian Angels.

18.verse: The space above the door leading into the Holy of Holies was also paneled. The walls were decorated with carvings of Guardian Angels, each with two faces, and of palm trees alternating with the Guardian Angels.

19.verse: One face—that of a man—looked toward the palm tree on one side, and the other face—that of a young lion—looked toward the palm tree on the other side. And so it was, all around the inner wall of the Temple.

20.verse: One face—that of a man—looked toward the palm tree on one side, and the other face—that of a young lion—looked toward the palm tree on the other side. And so it was, all around the inner wall of the Temple.

21.verse: There were square doorposts at the doors of the nave, and in front of the Holy of Holies was what appeared to be an altar, but it was made of wood.

22.verse: This altar was 3½ feet square and 5¼ feet high; its corners, base, and sides were all of wood. “This,” he told me, “is the Table of the Lord.”

23.verse: Both the nave and the Holy of Holies had double doors,

24.verse: each with two swinging sections.

25.verse: The doors leading into the nave were decorated with cherubim and palm trees, just as on the walls. And there was a wooden canopy over the entry hall.

26.verse: There were recessed windows and carved palm trees on both sides of the entry hall, the hallways beside the Temple, and on the canopy over the entrance.

1.verse: Then he led me out of the Temple, back into the inner court to the rooms north of the Temple yard, and to another building.

2.verse: This group of structures was 175 feet long by 87½ feet wide.

3.verse: The rows of rooms behind this building were the inner wall of the court. The rooms were in three tiers, overlooking the outer court on one side, and having a 35-foot strip of inner court on the other.

4.verse: A 17½-foot walk ran between the building and the tiers of rooms, extending the entire length, with the doors of the building facing north.

5.verse: The upper two tiers of rooms were not as wide as the lower one, because the upper tiers had wider walkways beside them.

6.verse: And since the building was not built with girders as those in the outer court were, the upper stories were set back from the ground floor.

7.verse: The north tiers, next to the outer court, were 87½ feet long—only half as long as the inner wing that faced the Temple court, which was 175 feet long. But a wall extended from the end of the shorter wing, parallel to the longer wing.

8.verse: The north tiers, next to the outer court, were 87½ feet long—only half as long as the inner wing that faced the Temple court, which was 175 feet long. But a wall extended from the end of the shorter wing, parallel to the longer wing.

9.verse: And there was an entrance from the outer court to these rooms from the east. On the opposite side of the Temple a similar building composed of two units of tiers was on the south side of the inner court, between the Temple and the outer court, arranged the same as the other.

10.verse: And there was an entrance from the outer court to these rooms from the east. On the opposite side of the Temple a similar building composed of two units of tiers was on the south side of the inner court, between the Temple and the outer court, arranged the same as the other.

11.verse: There was a walk between the two wings of the building, the same as in the other building across the court—the same length and width and the same exits and doors—they were identical units.

12.verse: And there was a door from the outer court at the east.

13.verse: Then he told me: “These north and south tiers of rooms facing the Temple yard are holy; there the priests who offer up the sacrifices to the Lord shall eat of the most holy offerings and store them—the cereal offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings, for these rooms are holy.

14.verse: When the priests leave the Holy Place—the nave of the Temple—they must change their clothes before going out to the outer court. The special robes in which they have been ministering must first be removed, for these robes are holy. They must put on other clothes before entering the parts of the building open to the public.”

15.verse: When he had finished making these measurements, he led me out through the east passageway to measure the entire Temple area.

16.verse: He found that it was in the form of a square, 875 feet long on each side, with a wall all around it to separate the restricted area from the public places.

17.verse: He found that it was in the form of a square, 875 feet long on each side, with a wall all around it to separate the restricted area from the public places.

1.verse: Afterward he brought me out again to the passageway through the outer wall leading to the east.

2.verse: And suddenly the glory of the God of Israel appeared from the east. The sound of his coming was like the roar of rushing waters, and the whole landscape lighted up with his glory.

3.verse: It was just as I had seen it in the other visions, first by the Chebar Canal, and then later at Jerusalem when he came to destroy the city. And I fell down before him with my face in the dust.

4.verse: And the glory of the Lord came into the Temple through the eastern passageway.

5.verse: Then the Spirit took me up and brought me into the inner court; and the glory of the Lord filled the Temple.

6.verse: And I heard the Lord speaking to me from within the Temple (the man who had been measuring was still standing beside me).

7.verse: And the Lord said to me: “Son of dust, this is the place of my throne and my footstool, where I shall remain, living among the people of Israel forever. They and their kings will not defile my holy name any longer through the adulterous worship of other gods or by worshiping the totem poles erected by their kings.

8.verse: They built their idol temples beside mine, with only a wall between, and worshiped their idols. Because they sullied my holy name by such wickedness, I consumed them in my anger.

9.verse: Now let them put away their idols and the totem poles erected by their kings, and I will live among them forever.

10.verse: “Son of dust, describe the Temple I have shown you to the people of Israel. Tell them its appearance and its plan so they will be ashamed of all their sins.

11.verse: And if they are truly ashamed of what they have done, then explain to them the details of its construction—its doors and entrances—and everything about it. Write out all the directions and the rules for them to keep.

12.verse: And this is the basic law of the Temple: Holiness! The entire top of the hill where the Temple is built is holy. Yes, this is the primary law concerning it.

13.verse: “And these are the measurements of the altar: The base is 21 inches high, with a 9-inch rim around its edge, and it extends 21 inches beyond the altar on all sides.

14.verse: The first stage of the altar is a stone platform 3½ feet high. This platform is 21 inches narrower than the base block on all sides. Rising from this is a narrower platform, 21 inches narrower on all sides, and 7 feet high.

15.verse: From it a still narrower platform rises 7 feet, and this is the top of the altar, with four horns projecting 21 inches up from the corners.

16.verse: This top platform of the altar is 21 feet square.

17.verse: The platform beneath it is 24½ feet square with a 10½-inch curb around the edges. The entire platform extends out from the top 21 inches on all sides. On the east side are steps to climb the altar.”

18.verse: And he said to me: “Son of dust, the Lord God says: These are the measurements of the altar to be made in the future, when it is erected for the burning of offerings and the sprinkling of blood upon it.

19.verse: At that time the Zadok family of the Levite tribe, who are my ministers, are to be given a bullock for a sin offering.

20.verse: You shall take some of its blood and smear it on the four horns of the altar and on the four corners of the top platform and in the curb around it. This will cleanse and make atonement for the altar.

21.verse: Then take the bullock for the sin offering and burn it at the appointed place outside the Temple area.

22.verse: “The second day, sacrifice a young male goat without any defects—without sickness, deformities, cuts, or scars—for a sin offering. Thus the altar shall be cleansed, as it was by the bullock.

23.verse: When you have finished this cleansing ceremony, offer another perfect bullock and a perfect ram from the flock.

24.verse: Present them before the Lord, and the priests shall sprinkle salt upon them as a burnt offering.

25.verse: “Every day for seven days a male goat, a bullock, and a ram from the flock shall be sacrificed as a sin offering. None are to have any defects or unhealthiness of any kind.

26.verse: Do this each day for seven days to cleanse and make atonement for the altar, thus consecrating it.

27.verse: On the eighth day, and on each day afterward, the priests will sacrifice on the altar the burnt offerings and thank offerings of the people, and I will accept you, says the Lord God.”

1.verse: Then the Lord brought me back to the outer wall’s eastern passageway, but it was closed.

2.verse: And he said to me: “This gate shall remain closed; it shall never be opened. No man shall pass through it; for the Lord, the God of Israel, entered here, and so it shall remain shut.

3.verse: Only the prince—because he is the prince—may sit inside the passageway to feast there before the Lord. But he shall go and come only through the entry hall of the passage.”

4.verse: Then he brought me through the north passageway to the front of the Temple. I looked and saw that the glory of the Lord filled the Temple of the Lord, and I fell to the ground with my face in the dust.

5.verse: And the Lord said to me: “Son of dust, notice carefully; use your eyes and ears. Listen to all I tell you about the laws and rules of the Temple of the Lord. Note carefully who may be admitted to the Temple and who is to be excluded from it.

6.verse: And say to these rebels, the people of Israel, ‘The Lord God says: O Israel, you have sinned greatly

7.verse: by letting the uncircumcised into my sanctuary—those who have no heart for God—when you offer me my food, the fat and the blood. Thus you have broken my covenant in addition to all your other sins.

8.verse: You have not kept the laws I gave you concerning these holy affairs, for you have hired foreigners to take charge of my sanctuary.’”

9.verse: The Lord God says: “No foreigner of all the many among you shall enter my sanctuary if he has not been circumcised and does not love the Lord.

10.verse: And the men of the tribe of Levi who abandoned me when Israel strayed away from God to idols must be punished for their unfaithfulness.

11.verse: They may be Temple guards and gatemen; they may slay the animals brought for burnt offerings and be present to help the people.

12.verse: But because they encouraged the people to worship other gods, causing Israel to fall into deep sin, I have raised my hand and taken oath,” says the Lord God, “that they must be punished.

13.verse: They shall not come near me to minister as priests; they may not touch any of my holy things, for they must bear their shame for all the sins they have committed.

14.verse: They are the Temple caretakers, to do maintenance work and to assist the people in a general way.

15.verse: “However, the sons of Zadok, of the tribe of Levi, continued as my priests in the Temple when Israel abandoned me for idols. These men shall be my ministers; they shall stand before me to offer the fat and blood of the sacrifices,” says the Lord God.

16.verse: “They shall enter my sanctuary and come to my Table to minister to me; they shall fulfill my requirements.

17.verse: “They must wear only linen clothing when they enter the passageway to the inner court, for they must wear no wool while on duty in the inner court or in the Temple.

18.verse: They must wear linen turbans and linen trousers; they must not wear anything that would cause them to perspire.

19.verse: When they return to the outer court, they must take off the clothes they wear while ministering to me, leaving them in the sacred chambers, and put on other clothes lest they harm the people by touching them with this clothing.

20.verse: “They must not let their hair grow too long nor shave it off. Regular, moderate haircuts are all they are allowed.

21.verse: No priest may drink wine before coming to the inner court.

22.verse: He may marry only a Jewish maiden, or the widow of a priest; he may not marry a divorced woman.

23.verse: “He shall teach my people the difference between what is holy and what is secular, what is right and what is wrong.

24.verse: “They will serve as judges to resolve any disagreements among my people. Their decisions must be based upon my laws. And the priests themselves shall obey my rules and regulations at all the sacred festivals, and they shall see to it that the Sabbath is kept a sacred day.

25.verse: “A priest must not defile himself by being in the presence of a dead person, unless it is his father, mother, child, brother, or unmarried sister. In such cases it is all right.

26.verse: But afterward he must wait seven days before he is cleansed and able to perform his Temple duties again.

27.verse: The first day he returns to work and enters the inner court and the sanctuary, he must offer a sin offering for himself,” the Lord God says.

28.verse: “As to property, they shall not own any, for I am their heritage! That is enough!

29.verse: “Their food shall be the gifts and sacrifices brought to the Temple by the people—the cereal offerings, the sin offerings, and the guilt offerings. Whatever anyone gives to the Lord shall be the priests’.

30.verse: The first of the first-ripe fruits and all the gifts for the Lord shall go to the priests. The first samples of each harvest of grain shall be donated to the priests too, so that the Lord will bless your homes.

31.verse: Priests may never eat meat from any bird or animal that dies a natural death or that dies after being attacked by other animals.

1.verse: “When you divide the land among the tribes of Israel, you shall first give a section of it to the Lord as his holy portion. This piece shall be 8⅓ miles long and 6⅔ miles wide. It shall all be holy ground.

2.verse: “A section of this land, 875 feet square, shall be designated for the Temple. An additional 87½-foot strip all around is to be left empty.

3.verse: The Temple shall be built within the area which is 8⅓ miles long and 3⅓ miles wide.

4.verse: All this section shall be holy land; it will be used by the priests, who minister in the sanctuary, for their homes and for my Temple.

5.verse: “The strip next to it, 8⅓ miles long and 3⅓ miles wide, shall be the residence area for the Levites who work at the Temple.

6.verse: Adjacent to the holy lands will be a section 8⅓ miles by 1⅔ miles for a city open to everyone in Israel.

7.verse: “Two special sections of land shall be set apart for the prince—one on each side of the holy lands and city; it is contiguous with them in length, and its eastern and western boundaries are the same as those of the tribal sections.

8.verse: This shall be his allotment. My princes shall no longer oppress and rob my people but shall assign all the remainder of the land to the people, giving a portion to each tribe.”

9.verse: For the Sovereign Lord says to the rulers: “Quit robbing and cheating my people out of their land and expelling them from their homes. Always be fair and honest.

10.verse: You must use honest scales, honest bushels, honest gallons.

11.verse: A homer (about five bushels) shall be your standard unit of measurement for both liquid and dry measure. Smaller units shall be the ephah (about a half bushel) for dry measure, and the bath (about seventeen quarts) for liquid.

12.verse: The unit of weight shall be the silver shekel (about half an ounce); it must always be exchanged for twenty gerahs, no less; five shekels shall be valued at five shekels, no less; and ten shekels at ten shekels! Fifty shekels shall always equal one mina.

13.verse: “This is the tax you must give to the prince: a bushel of wheat or barley for every sixty you reap;

14.verse: and one percent of your olive oil;

15.verse: from each 200 sheep in all your flocks in Israel, give him one sheep. These are the meal offerings, burnt offerings, and thank offerings to make atonement for those who bring them,” says the Lord God.

16.verse: “All the people of Israel shall bring their offerings to the prince.

17.verse: “The prince shall be required to furnish the people with sacrifices for public worship—sin offerings, burnt offerings, meal offerings, drink offerings, and thank offerings—to make reconciliation for the people of Israel. This shall be done at the time of the religious feasts, the new moon ceremonies, the Sabbaths, and all other similar occasions.”

18.verse: The Lord God says: “On each New Year’s Day sacrifice a young bull with no blemishes, to purify the Temple.

19.verse: The priest shall take some of the blood of this sin offering and put it on the doorposts of the Temple, upon the four corners of the base of the altar, and upon the walls at the entry of the inner court.

20.verse: Do this also on the seventh day of that month for anyone who has sinned through error or ignorance, and so the Temple will be cleansed.

21.verse: “On the fourteenth day of the same month, you shall celebrate the Passover. It will be a seven-day feast. Only bread without yeast shall be eaten during those days.

22.verse: On the day of Passover the prince shall provide a young bull for a sin offering for himself and all the people of Israel.

23.verse: On each of the seven days of the feast he shall prepare a burnt offering to the Lord. This daily offering will consist of seven young bulls and seven rams without blemish. A male goat shall also be given each day for a sin offering.

24.verse: And the prince shall provide a half bushel of grain with each bullock and ram for a meal offering, and three quarts of olive oil.

25.verse: “Early in October during each of the seven days of the annual festival of shelters, he shall provide these same sacrifices for the sin offering, burnt offering, meal offering, and oil offering.”

1.verse: The Lord God says: “The inner wall’s eastern entrance shall be closed during the six work days but open on the Sabbath and on the days of the new moon celebrations.

2.verse: The prince shall enter the outside entry hall of the passageway and proceed to the inner wall at the other end while the priest offers his burnt offering and peace offering. He shall worship inside the passageway and then return back to the entrance, which shall not be closed until evening.

3.verse: The people shall worship the Lord in front of this passageway on the Sabbaths and on the days of the new moon celebrations.

4.verse: “The burnt offering that the prince sacrifices to the Lord on the Sabbath days shall be six lambs and a ram, all unblemished.

5.verse: He shall present a meal offering of a half bushel of flour to go with the ram and whatever amount he is willing to give with each lamb. And he shall bring three quarts of olive oil for each half bushel of flour.

6.verse: At the new moon celebration, he shall bring one young bull in perfect condition, six lambs, and one ram, all without any blemish.

7.verse: With the young bull, he must bring a half bushel of flour for a meal offering. With the ram he must bring a half bushel* of flour. With the lamb he is to bring whatever he is willing to give. With each half bushel of grain he is to bring three quarts of olive oil.

8.verse: “The prince shall go in at the entry hall of the passageway and out the same way;

9.verse: but when the people come in through the north passageway to sacrifice during the religious feasts, they must go out through the south passageway. Those coming in from the south must go out by the north. They must never go out the same way they come in, but must always use the opposite passageway.

10.verse: The prince shall enter and leave with the common people on these occasions.

11.verse: “To summarize: At the special feasts and sacred festivals the meal offering shall be a half bushel with the young bull; a half bushel with the ram; as much as the prince is willing to give with each lamb; and three quarts of oil with each half bushel of grain.

12.verse: Whenever the prince offers an extra burnt offering or peace offering to be sacrificed to the Lord, the inner eastern gate shall be opened up for him to enter, and he shall offer his sacrifices just as on the Sabbaths. Then he shall turn around and go out, and the passage shall be shut behind him.

13.verse: “Each morning a yearling lamb must be sacrificed as a burnt offering to the Lord.

14.verse: And there must be a meal offering each morning—five pounds of flour with one quart of oil with which to mix it. This is a permanent ordinance—the lamb, the grain offering, and the olive oil shall be provided every morning for the daily sacrifice.”

15.verse: And there must be a meal offering each morning—five pounds of flour with one quart of oil with which to mix it. This is a permanent ordinance—the lamb, the grain offering, and the olive oil shall be provided every morning for the daily sacrifice.”

16.verse: The Sovereign Lord says: “If the prince gives a gift of land to one of his sons, it will belong to him forever.

17.verse: But if he gives a gift of land to one of his servants, the servant may keep it only until the Year of Release (every seventh year) when he is set free; then the land returns to the prince. Only gifts to his sons are permanent.

18.verse: And the prince may never take anyone’s property by force. If he gives property to his sons, it must be from his own land, for I don’t want my people losing their property and having to move away.”

19.verse: After that, using the door through the wall at the side of the main passageway, he led me through the entrance to the block of sacred chambers that faced north. There, at the extreme west end of these rooms, I saw a place where, my guide told me, the priests boil the meat of the trespass offering and sin offering and bake the flour of the flour offerings into bread. They do it here to avoid the necessity of carrying the sacrifices through the outer court, in case they harm the people.

20.verse: After that, using the door through the wall at the side of the main passageway, he led me through the entrance to the block of sacred chambers that faced north. There, at the extreme west end of these rooms, I saw a place where, my guide told me, the priests boil the meat of the trespass offering and sin offering and bake the flour of the flour offerings into bread. They do it here to avoid the necessity of carrying the sacrifices through the outer court, in case they harm the people.

21.verse: Then he brought me out to the outer court again and led me to each of the four corners of the court. I saw that in each corner there was a room 70 feet long by 52½ feet wide, enclosed by walls.

22.verse: Then he brought me out to the outer court again and led me to each of the four corners of the court. I saw that in each corner there was a room 70 feet long by 52½ feet wide, enclosed by walls.

23.verse: Around the inside of these walls there ran a line of brick boiling vats with ovens underneath.

24.verse: He said these rooms were where the Temple assistants—the Levites—boil the sacrifices the people offer.

1.verse: Then he brought me back to the door of the Temple. I saw a stream flowing eastward from beneath the Temple and passing to the right of the altar, that is, on its south side.

2.verse: Then he brought me outside the wall through the north passageway and around to the eastern entrance, where I saw the stream flowing along on the south side of the eastern passageway.*

3.verse: Measuring as he went, he took me 1,500 feet east along the stream and told me to go across. At that point the water was up to my ankles.

4.verse: He measured off another 1,500 feet and told me to cross again. This time the water was up to my knees.

5.verse: Fifteen hundred feet after that it was up to my waist. Another 1,500 feet and it had become a river so deep I wouldn’t be able to get across unless I were to swim. It was too deep to cross on foot.

6.verse: He told me to keep in mind what I had seen, then led me back along the bank.

7.verse: And now, to my surprise, many trees were growing on both sides of the river!

8.verse: He told me: “This river flows east through the desert and the Jordan Valley to the Dead Sea, where it will heal the salty waters and make them fresh and pure.

9.verse: Everything touching the water of this river shall live. Fish will abound in the Dead Sea, for its waters will be healed. Wherever this water flows, everything will live.

10.verse: Fishermen will stand along the shores of the Dead Sea, fishing all the way from En-gedi to En-eglaim. The shores will be filled with nets drying in the sun. Fish of every kind will fill the Dead Sea just as they do the Mediterranean!

11.verse: But the marshes and swamps will not be healed; they will still be salty.

12.verse: All kinds of fruit trees will grow along the riverbanks. The leaves will never turn brown and fall, and there will always be fruit. There will be a new crop every month—without fail! For they are watered by the river flowing from the Temple. The fruit will be for food and the leaves for medicine.”

13.verse: The Lord God says: “Here are the instructions for dividing the land to the twelve tribes of Israel: The tribe of Joseph (Ephraim and Manasseh) shall be given two sections.

14.verse: Otherwise, each tribe will have an equal share. I promised with hand raised in oath of truth to give the land to your fathers, and you shall inherit it now.

15.verse: “The northern boundary will run from the Mediterranean toward Hethlon, then on through Labweh to Zedad;

16.verse: then to Berothah and Sibraim, which are on the border between Damascus and Hamath, and finally to Hazer-hatticon, on the border of Hauran.

17.verse: So the northern border will be from the Mediterranean to Hazar-enan, on the border with Hamath to the north and Damascus to the south.

18.verse: “The eastern border will run south from Hazar-enan to Mount Hauran, where it will bend westward to the Jordan at the southern tip of the Sea of Galilee, and down along the Jordan River separating Israel from Gilead, past the Dead Sea to Tamar.

19.verse: “The southern border will go west from Tamar to the springs at Meribath-kadesh and then follow the course of the brook of Egypt (Wadi el-Arish) to the Mediterranean.

20.verse: “On the west side, the Mediterranean itself will be your boundary, from the southern boundary to the point where the northern boundary begins.

21.verse: “Divide the land within these boundaries among the tribes of Israel.

22.verse: Distribute the land as an inheritance for yourselves and for the foreigners who live among you with their families. All children born in the land—whether or not their parents are foreigners—are to be considered citizens and have the same rights your own children have.

23.verse: All these immigrants are to be given land according to the tribe where they now live.

1.verse: “Here is the list of the tribes and the territory each is to get. For Dan: From the northwest boundary at the Mediterranean, across to Hethlon, then to Labweh, and then on to Hazar-enan on the border between Damascus to the south and Hamath to the north. Those are the eastern and western limits of the land.

2.verse: Asher’s territory lies south of Dan’s and has the same east and west boundaries.

3.verse: Naphtali’s land lies south of Asher’s, with the same boundary lines on the east and the west.

4.verse: Then comes Manasseh, south of Naphtali, with the same eastern and western boundary lines.

5.verse: Next, to the south, is Ephraim, and then Reuben and then Judah, all with the same boundaries on the east and the west.

6.verse: Next, to the south, is Ephraim, and then Reuben and then Judah, all with the same boundaries on the east and the west.

7.verse: Next, to the south, is Ephraim, and then Reuben and then Judah, all with the same boundaries on the east and the west.

8.verse: “South of Judah is the land set aside for the Temple. It has the same eastern and western boundaries as the tribal units, with the Temple in the center.

9.verse: This Temple area will be 8⅓ miles long and 6⅔ miles wide.

10.verse: “A strip of land measuring 8⅓ miles long by 3⅓ miles wide, north to south, surrounds the Temple.

11.verse: It is for the priests, that is, the sons of Zadok who obeyed me and didn’t go into sin when the people of Israel and the rest of their tribe of Levi did.

12.verse: It is their special portion when the land is distributed, the most sacred land of all. Next to it lies the area where the other Levites will live.

13.verse: It will be of the same size and shape as the first. Together they measure 8⅓ miles by 6⅔ miles.

14.verse: None of this special land shall ever be sold or traded or used by others, for it belongs to the Lord; it is holy.

15.verse: “The strip of land 8⅓ miles long by 1⅔ miles wide, south of the Temple section, is for public use—homes, pasture, and parks, with a city in the center.

16.verse: The city itself is to be 1½ miles square.

17.verse: Open land for pastures shall surround the city for approximately a tenth of a mile.

18.verse: Outside the city, stretching east and west for three miles alongside the holy grounds, is garden area belonging to the city, for public use.

19.verse: It is open to anyone working in the city, no matter where he comes from in Israel.

20.verse: “The entire area—including sacred lands and city lands—is 8⅓ miles square.

21.verse: “The land on both sides of this area, extending clear out to the eastern and western boundaries of Israel, shall belong to the prince. This land, lying between the sections allotted to Judah and Benjamin, is 8⅓ miles square on each side of the sacred and city lands.

22.verse: “The land on both sides of this area, extending clear out to the eastern and western boundaries of Israel, shall belong to the prince. This land, lying between the sections allotted to Judah and Benjamin, is 8⅓ miles square on each side of the sacred and city lands.

23.verse: “The sections given to the remaining tribes are as follows: Benjamin’s section extends across the entire country of Israel, from its eastern border clear across to the western border.

24.verse: South of Benjamin’s area lies that of Simeon, also extending out to these same eastern and western borders.

25.verse: Next is Issachar, with the same boundaries.

26.verse: Then comes Zebulun, also extending all the way across.

27.verse: Then Gad, with the same borders on east and west, while its south border runs from Tamar to the springs at Meribath-kadesh, and then follows the brook of Egypt (Wadi el-Arish) to the Mediterranean.

28.verse: Then Gad, with the same borders on east and west, while its south border runs from Tamar to the springs at Meribath-kadesh, and then follows the brook of Egypt (Wadi el-Arish) to the Mediterranean.

29.verse: These are the allotments to be made to each tribe,” says the Lord God.

30.verse: “Each city gate will be named in honor of one of the tribes of Israel. On the north side, with its 1½-mile wall, there will be three gates, one named for Reuben, one for Judah, and one for Levi.

31.verse: “Each city gate will be named in honor of one of the tribes of Israel. On the north side, with its 1½-mile wall, there will be three gates, one named for Reuben, one for Judah, and one for Levi.

32.verse: On the east side, with its 1½-mile wall, the gates will be named for Joseph, Benjamin, and Dan.

33.verse: The south wall, also the same length, will have the gates of Simeon, Issachar, and Zebulun;

34.verse: on the 1½ miles of the west side, they will be named for Gad, Asher, and Naphtali.

35.verse: “The entire circumference of the city is six miles. And the name of the city will be ‘The City of God.’”
